ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Economic analysis of everyday actions and trends.
Basics of microeconomics
Learned basic microeconomics.
I learned a lot of valuable information about microeconomics.
I learnt the conceptual and mathematical basics of microeconomics.

I learned a lot more about the basic economic ideas underlying a lot of economic decisions. I was also able to gain a broader understanding of economics than I had from my high school economics class.

I received a rigorous introduction to microeconomic theory. I learned how to translate problems into words and clearly drawn diagrams. I look forward to taking intro macro in Fall 2022 to complete my foundation in economic theory that I can then apply to real-world contexts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More divided grading - not as much weight on final edwm
Great slides and content format. Problem sets were accurate for what we were expected to know. However problem sets were much harder and complicated than example problems in class.

Strengths: Professor Reiche is great. The lectures are well done, and I rarely felt lost.
Weaknesses: None come to mind. I'm not certain that we covered everything on the syllabus (because Prof. Reiche always spent time answering questions, so we slowed her down), but I think that's fine as long as we're prepared for future econ classes (and we have the textbook for our own reference).

The professor was good and the powerpoint slides were very useful for learning. I wish that the textbook had been incorporated more into this course, as I gained a lot whenever I read it, but not other students read the textbook and there was too much other work to consistently read the textbook pages. I also wish that there was more conceptual background, as opposed to pure math.

It was a pretty good introduction to Econ but it may have been way too fast paced for people starting from scratch. I also expected way more theory than there was - it was much mathier than I thought it would be.

It was nice how the lectures of this course were posted and how students were able to speak to the professor directly during class. However, despite being a seminar class, the level of personal learning experience was a lot lower than I had hoped, and often felt like there was not enough help to meet student need. I know this is often an issue with lectures, but surprisingly, I also found it to be an issue with this class.

Strengths: The seminar was well-taught. I was able to freely ask questions during lectures and engage deeply with the material in office hours. The size of the class was just right, with not too many students. 

Weaknesses: None!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, would probably take the lecture instead.
Yes. Definitely take Econ 110 with Prof. Reiche. She reviews a lot of the material at the start of the lecture and always stops to answer questions.
Yes, this course was very good for introducing microeconomics. I have not taken an econ lecture, so cannot compare these. But I had a good experience in this class.
Sure but only if you have a strong background/inclination towards math and calculus! The course is more math and less theory.
I would recommend this course to another student just because the information is useful and can be applied beyond an economics class.

Yes. If the student wants to receive a rigorous introduction to microeconomic theory, then please take this course. I, in this course, learned to love econ for its ability to translate abstract theory into dynamic, real-world models of human economic behavior.
